title: Drivers ‘should be fined more’ for leaving engines running when parked
text:

If you leave your engine running when parked up, you risk a £20 fine from the council.

However, given how thin councils are stretched, and how low the fine is, you've got a very small chance of getting one.

And that's something people increasingly think should change.

RAC head of roads policy Nicholas Lyes said: "Councils already have the powers to deal with this problem, but few are currently doing so."

He added: "While the law is already in place for idling, enforcement is limited if not non-existent."

But that could change, as people become more aware of the impact on air quality and carbon emissions.

Figures from the RAC show almost three drivers in four (72%) want councils to take action against people burning fuel while parked.

And large numbers of those (44%) think it's time for a crackdown from officials.

(Image: Universal Images Group via Getty)

"Many of the drivers we questioned would like to see some firm action taken against offenders. This is no doubt needed to bring about a change in behaviour," Lyes said.

"You could liken the current situation with engine idling to that of taking your own carrier bags to the supermarket: everyone knew it was the right thing to do, but few of us did it until a compulsory charge was introduced."

In June, the Department for Transport announced it intends to launch a public consultation looking at increasing fines for idling drivers.

Councils responded by saying they had chosen to educate where possible, rather than punish.

(Image: Getty)

Local Government Association transport spokesman David Renard said: "Councils have prioritised changing behaviour by educating motorists, which is often more effective than issuing fines.

"As part of their review of air quality legislation, the Government should look again at whether these powers are working how they intended and whether they could be made simpler to use while still being fair to the motorist."

He added: “Although fines to drivers who leave their engines idling are issued as a last resort, the legislation to enable this is hard to enforce in practice."

He said councils were also looking at other measures to reduce air pollution, including working with schools to set up car free streets to prevent engine idling, encouraging the use of electric vehicles with recharging points, promoting cycling, managing air pollution monitoring networks and introducing clean air zones.
description: Leaving the motor running when parked carries a small fine, but there's growing support for increasing it as well making sure councils take action more often
